name: 賴冠廷
objective:
The goal of this course is to give students a broad overview of state-of-the-art deep learning algorithms, and teach students how to develop deep learning applications by hands-on coding examples. Most examples taught in this class are based on the TensorFlow framework. We will cover many different fields including image classification, object detection, natural language processing, reinforcement learning, embedded deep learning and generative adversarial networks. The syllabus is listed as follows:
•	Number and Character recognition
•	Image Classification for 1000 categories
•	Object Detection for 9000 objects
•	Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN)
•	Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN)
•	Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM)
•	Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN)
•	Embedded Deep Learning Algorithms
•	Deep Reinforcement Learning
schedule:
1.	Introduction to Deep Learning (Francois (2017), Chapter 1, 2, 3)
2.	Applied Math for Machine Learning (Ian et al. (2017), Chapter 2, 3, 4) 
3.	Fundamentals of Machine Learning (Francois (2017), Chapter 4 + Ian et al. (2017), 5)
4.	TensorFlow & Keras + Word Embedding
5.	Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Image Classification (Francois (2017), Chapter 5)
6.	Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) and Long Short-term Memory (LSTM)
7.	Object Detection
        a. YOLO 9000 – You Only Look Once
        b. Single-shot Multi-Box Detection
8.	Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN)
9.	Deep Reinforcement Learning
        a. OpenAI GYM
        b. Training Autonomous Vehicles in Virtual Reality
10.	Virtual Environment for Visual Deep Learning
11.	Embedded Deep Learning
12.	Student Project Demos
materials:
Francois Chollet, “Deep Learning with Python, ” Manning, 2017
Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, and Aaron Courville, “Deep Learning,” MIT Press, 2017
Latest publications on CVPR, NIPS, ICML, AAAI, ICLR
